%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%% Textclass specific LaTeX commands.
%% Map the lyx-friendly SmartQuestion style to exam environments
%% See http://tex.stackexchange.com/a/319996/17868
\newcounter{mydepth}%
\newcommand{\myenvironmentname}{%
\ifnum\value{mydepth}=0notinquestion\fi%
\ifnum\value{mydepth}=1question\fi%
\ifnum\value{mydepth}=2part\fi%
\ifnum\value{mydepth}=3subpart\fi%
\ifnum\value{mydepth}=4subsubpart\fi%
\ifnum\value{mydepth}>4undefinedquestion\fi%
}%
\newcommand{\myquestion}{\csname \myenvironmentname\endcsname}%
\newenvironment{myquestions}%
  {\stepcounter{mydepth}\begin{\myenvironmentname s}}%
  {\end{\myenvironmentname s}\addtocounter{mydepth}{-1}}%

% code to rewrite \mychoice or \mychoice[] to \choice or \CorrectChoice respectively
% see http://tex.stackexchange.com/a/319470/17868
\def\mychoice{\@ifnextchar[{\@with}{\@without}}
\def\@with[#1]{\CorrectChoice}
\def\@without{\choice}


\makeatother

\noindent \newpage{}\vspace{0.1in}

\begin{myquestions}
\myquestion[30] Consider a dinner at a \textbf{circular table} with a total of $N\geq4$
(distinct) guests including Barbie (B), Ken (K), and the famous probabilist
Émile Borel (E). B, K, and E wish to sit together (i.e., there cannot
be another guest between any two of them). How many possible arrangements
satisfy this requirement?

\newpage{}
\begin{solution}
Label the seats $s_{1},\ldots,s_{N}$.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Consider the case that $s_{i}=B$, $s_{i+1}=K$, and $s_{i+2}=E$.
In this case, the remaining guests can be arranged in $(N-3)!$ ways.
Since $1\leq i\leq N-2$, there are $(N-2)(N-3)!$ such arrangements.
\item Consider the case that $s_{N-1}=B$, $s_{N}=K$, and $s_{1}=E$. In
this case, the remaining guests can be arranged in $(N-3)!$ ways.
\item Consider the case that $s_{N}=B$, $s_{1}=K$, and $s_{2}=E$. In
this case, the remaining guests can be arranged in $(N-3)!$ ways.
\item Since we can permute $B$, $K$, and $E$ to obtain another valid
arrangement, we have a total of
\[
3!\left(N-3\right)!\left(2+N-2\right)=3!N\left(N-3\right)!
\]
\end{enumerate}
\end{solution}

\myquestion[35] Let $X$ and $Y$ be \textbf{independent} real-valued random variables
defined on some probability space. Let $f\colon\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$
and $g\colon\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ be \textbf{monotone
bijective} Borel measurable functions. Show that $f\circ X$ and $g\circ Y$
are also independent.

\textbf{Hint}: two random variables $U$ and $W$ are said to be independent
if 
\[
\mathbb{P}(\{U\leq u\}\cap\{W\leq w\})=\mathbb{P}\{U\leq u\}\mathbb{P}\{W\leq w\}
\]
 for all choices of $u,w\in\mathbb{R}$. 

\newpage{}
\begin{solution}
This follows from
\begin{align*}
\mathbb{P}(\left\{ f(X)\leq u\right\} \cap\left\{ g(Y)\leq w\right\} ) & =\mathbb{P}(\left\{ X\leq f^{-1}(u)\right\} \cap\left\{ Y\leq g^{-1}(w)\right\} )\\
 & =\mathbb{P}\left\{ X\leq f^{-1}(u)\right\} \mathbb{P}\left\{ Y\leq g^{-1}(w)\right\} \\
 & =\mathbb{P}\left\{ f(X)\leq u\right\} \mathbb{P}\left\{ g(Y)\leq w\right\} \\
 & =\mathbb{P}(\left\{ f(X)\leq u\right\} \cap\left\{ g(Y)\leq w\right\} ).
\end{align*}
\end{solution}

\myquestion[35] Let $(X_{n})_{n}$ be a sequence of random variables that are bounded
from below by an integrable random variable $Y$ (i.e., $X_{n}\geq Y$
a.s. for each $n$). Suppose that $\lim_{n}X_{n}=X$ a.s. Show that
$\mathbb{E}[X]\leq\sup_{n}\mathbb{E}[X_{n}]$.

\textbf{Hint}: Fatou's lemma states that when $(W_{n})_{n}$ is a
sequence of nonnegative random variables, $\mathbb{E}[\liminf_{n}W_{n}]\leq\liminf_{n}\mathbb{E}[W_{n}]$.
\begin{solution}
Let
\[
W_{n}=X_{n}-Y.
\]
Applying Fatou's lemma,
\begin{align*}
\mathbb{E}[X-Y] & =\mathbb{E}[\lim_{n}X_{n}-Y]\\
 & =\mathbb{E}[\liminf_{n}W_{n}]\\
 & \leq\liminf_{n}\mathbb{E}[W_{n}]\\
 & \leq\limsup_{n}\mathbb{E}[W_{n}]\\
 & =\inf_{n}\sup_{m\geq n}\mathbb{E}[W_{m}]\\
 & \leq\sup_{n}\mathbb{E}[W_{n}]\\
 & =\sup_{n}\mathbb{E}[X_{n}-Y].
\end{align*}
\end{solution}

\end{myquestions}
